awd_titl_txt: MRI Consortium: Development of Instrumentation for the PICO-500 Bubble Chamber
awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays. PICO, a merger of the PICASSO and COUPP collaborations, employs room-temperature super-heated liquids to search for dark matter particle candidates. Previous efforts by PICO at SNOLAB have resulted in a world-leading sensitivity to spin-dependent WIMP-proton couplings. Recent progress in acoustic discrimination against alpha particles and particulate-induced backgrounds will enable the next-generation of PICO bubble chambers to also lead in sensitivity to spin-independent couplings in the WIMP mass range below 10 GeV/c^2. The group has aided the broader scientific community by fabricating specially designed transducers. Several astrophysics experiments are now using acoustic particle identification. The group has also been working with a luthier to develop techniques to measure wood properties and design jazz arch top guitars with predictable sound. A liquid xenon bubble chamber experiment was outfitted with cryogenic-safe transducers to correlate scintillation light with bubble images. The PSU group has developed novel radiopure piezoceramics with properties suggesting ten times greater sensitivity than the best current PZT formulations.

This award provides funds to enable the Indiana University South Bend (IUSB), North Eastern Illinois University (NEIU), and Penn State groups to develop hardware and software components of the ton-scale PICO-500 bubble chamber which will be the most sensitive detector for a wide variety of dark matter particle candidates and will serve over 20 research groups around the world. PICO uses superheated liquids to search for the tiny energy depositions left by nuclei recoiling due to collisions with dark matter. These depositions cause the liquid to explosively transform into gas. The IUSB group has designed and fabricated all of the acoustic transducers for the previous detectors. In 2008 the group discovered that it is possible to differentiate the sounds of bubbles created by nuclear recoils from those initiated by alpha decay (the main background). The NEIU team has worked on improving the control and display software necessary for operating the detector. The PSU team has been responsible for fabricating piezoelectric ceramics from radiopure oxides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: For nearly a century, astronomical measurements have provided evidence that approximately 85% of the matter in the universe is in some exotic form, unlike the atom. This matter is inherently invisible, interacting extremely weakly with the atoms which we can see. Yet, because of its enormous mass, it is the architect of all of the structures which we can see, such as galaxies, stars, planets and people. However, despite great efforts, physicists have as yet been unable to convincingly detect individual bits (particles) of that matter. 

PICO-500  is a ton-scale detector with unprecedented sensitivity to a variety of candidate types of these kinds of particles which are thought to interact with atoms via the weak nuclear force and gravity. The detector is used to superheat liquids gently just past their boiling temperature. The liquid remains stable until an atom is disturbed by being bumped by a dark matter particle or by the decay of one of the minute numbers of radioactive atoms that contaminate even the cleanest liquids ever purified by man. The disturbed superheated liquid will then explosively transform into a gas, making the interaction easy to detect with cameras and acoustic sensors. 

In 2008, the PICASSO experiment demonstrated that acoustic transducers made by IUSB (figures 1&2), using radioactively pure piezoelectric ceramics (fabricated by PSU) as the sensing elements inside the transducers (figures 3&4),were able to distinguish acoustically between gas bubbles formed by radioactive background events and those made by dark matter scattering (mimicked by neutron calibration sources). 

The IUSB, NEIU and PSU groups designed and fabricated the hardware, software and data acquisition systems for three subsystems of the PICO-500 experiment - the acoustic system (including optimizing the piezoceramic formulation to maximize sensitivity (figure 5), the temperature monitoring and the fast pressure-rise system (the last is used as a secondary bubble counting system and to prevent runaway phase change of all of the liquid in the detector). The radio-pure piezoelectric ceramic composition and microstructure was improved to provide the suitable figure of merit required for the high sensitivity in the acoustic transducers. In addition, Co-PI Harris assumed responsibility for the event display software and data management devices for the experiment (figure 6). 

At the end of this grant, the team has written all of the software for the event display, purchased and fabricated all components of these three systems, except for the final assembly of the acoustic transducers themselves. This final step is awaiting a decision by the collaboration about desired characteristics of the IUSB embedded preamplifiers and for collaboration machining time of a large batch of the new type of enclosure (figure 2) for the transducers.

 

Broader Impacts:

On this grant, the IUSB team provided research projects for 11 undergraduates, 4 high school students and 2 high school science teachers. The PSU team provided training for research faculty that developed novel manufacturing method for piezoelectric elements and conducted tutorials for multiple K-12 students. The NEIU team provided research projects for 9 undergraduate students. 

The development of the acoustic transducers led Levine and Priya to a new way of looking at the dynamics of large ice formations such as glaciers and the polar ice caps by use of strings of sacrificial sound sensors to supplement current techniques which use seismometers and photography by satellites.

Work on improved (structured) PZT ceramics for PICO has spurred research by Priya and  Levine to develop non-leaded piezoceramic materials which should be lower in radioactive contamination than PZT.  This material might also prove useful to the liquid argon bubble chamber experiment (SBC) and to the liquid rocket industry which uses piezoelectric sensors inside the cryogenic fuel tanks for data collection during flight. 

Because of the technical abilities of the students at IUSB developed in this project, the group was invited to participate in a NOAA-funded  large-scale test of a shark bycatch reduction strategy. Shark bycatch is by far the largest driver of pressures on shark populations, and this is a problem that marine biologists have been trying to solve for decades. IUSB developed and mass produced (350 active units, 400 control units) a device which could be attached to hooks to emit time-varying electric fields around the baited hooks. Sharks have electric field sensing organs, while the target fish do not. The hypothesis was that this would startle/scare away the sharks without scaring away the tuna and salmon etc. 

 A long line fishing vessel deployed 20 sets with thousands of hooks exposure and confirmed in the summer of 2023 that there is roughly a 50% reduction in the rate of sharks caught on hooks with IUSB  shark ticklers, compared with hooks fitted with control units and no effects on target fish. Analysis of the data is nearly complete and a paper is in the later stages of preparation.
